Unless otherwise indicated, references to FY23 and 2023 and FY22 and 2022 in graphs and copy throughout this report refer to IAGÃ¢ÂÂs financial years ending 30 June 2023 and 2022, respectively. All figures are in Australian dollars unless otherwise stated.

Our External Auditor is KPMG, and our current lead audit partner is Brendan Twining. The BAC is responsible for the appointment, evaluation, Management and removal of the External Auditor and the approval of their annual fees (subject to shareholder approval where required).

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: The Board, with assistance from the NomCom, conducts a formal selection process before appointing new INEDs. External consultants may also be engaged to help identify suitable candidates. All candidates for Board positions undergo comprehensive background checks (including Police and Bankruptcy checks) and assessment under IAGÃ¢ÂÂs Fit and Proper Policy before they are appointed.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: The Board comprises 10 Independent Non-Executive Directors (INEDs), the Managing Director and the Chief Executive Officer (CEO).

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: Providing effective leadership and guidance for the Board and IAG; Maintaining an open dialogue with the CEO and Management; Facilitating communication between the Directors and between the Board and Management, including by liaising with the Group Company Secretary concerning the BoardÃ¢ÂÂs information requirements to assist the Board with effective decision-making; and Chairing the Annual General Meeting (AGM) and representing the Board and GroupÃ¢ÂÂs views to stakeholders, including Shareholders, regulators and the community.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: The Board delegates certain powers to its standing Board Committees to help it fulfil its roles and responsibilities. In addition to the BoardÃ¢ÂÂs standing Committees, the Board establishes ad hoc Committees as and when required. The Board also delegates specific powers to the CEO, who, in turn, delegates some of those powers to Group Executives and other Officers under delegations of authority. The CEO is accountable to the Board for exercising those delegated powers and ManagementÃ¢ÂÂs performance.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: IAG is responsible for managing the environmental, social and governance (ESG) risks and opportunities impacting IAGÃ¢ÂÂs business and the communities in which we operate. We align ESG considerations with our broader strategic ambitions to generate longer-term value for our shareholders, customers, and communities.

Conflicts of interest, including related party transactions, are a standing agenda item considered by the Board and Board Committees at each Meeting and in each paper presented to the Board or Board Committee. If a potential conflict is identified, the relevant Director or the Board may determine that they should not receive documents related to or participate in discussions or decisions. To further ensure independence from Management, the Board and Board Committees meet regularly without Management present.

Our Continuous Disclosure Committee is responsible for managing IAGÃ¢ÂÂs continuous disclosure obligations daily, including determining whether a disclosure is required and approving the form (unless it is a Board reserved or procedural matter). It is also responsible for IAGÃ¢ÂÂs reporting processes, controls and guidelines for releasing market announcements and referring issues to the Board or through the rapid response process.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: The BoardÃ¢ÂÂs Skills Matrix (Skills Matrix) sets out the skills and experience considered essential to the effectiveness of the Board and its Committees. It is reviewed annually to ensure the prescribed skills and experience address IAGÃ¢ÂÂs existing and emerging strategic, business and governance issues and that DirectorsÃ¢ÂÂ skill level ratings remain current. The Skills Matrix identifies potential director candidates as part of the ongoing Board renewal process.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column7: The Board continuously reviews its performance and the performance of its Committees and individual Directors and recognises the importance of this to Board effectiveness. The annual Board performance reviews are conducted either internally or with the assistance of an independent external consultant.

column13: We review our Remuneration Framework's (including the Group Remuneration Policy) effectiveness and compliance with relevant regulatory requirements. A review of the Executive Remuneration Framework was completed during FY23.

The Board incorporated the requirements of CPS 511 into the comprehensive review of our Executive remuneration framework completed during FY23. The Board Chair and I met with several proxy advisors and critical investors in June 2023 before finalising our thinking on the FY24 Executive remuneration framework. These discussions have shaped the outcome. The result of the review is several changes, designed not only to meet both the letter and spirit of CPS 511 but also to ensure the framework remains fit for purpose, market competitive, support us in delivering IAG's strategy and align with shareholder outcomes.

column7: The annual total compensation ratio male to female (average) is 1,05.

We conduct an annual materiality assessment to inform our enterprise-wide sustainability priorities, strategy setting and risk management processes. This financial year, we re-validated that our four material topics for IAG to address remain consistent with the FY22 assessment: climate change, disaster resilience and emergency response, affordability and availability of insurance, and trust and transparency.

column13: The Group Continuous Disclosure Policy (Disclosure Policy) governs how we communicate with the market and the investment community. We have systems, frameworks, and processes to manage compliance with relevant laws and regulations, including an independent Risk and Compliance Division, policies and processes, reporting and incident management procedures, and training programs.

IAG's Group Whistleblower Policy outlines the rights and responsibilities of people involved in a whistleblowing report or investigation. Employees and others identifying that something is wrong are encouraged to speak up.

IAG has a Fit and Proper Policy (F&P Policy) that addresses the requirements of APRA Prudential Standard CPS 520 Fit and Proper. The F&P Policy requires an assessment before the appointment and an annual evaluation after that of Directors and certain members of Senior Management and responsible auditors, including determining whether they have the appropriate skills, experience, and knowledge to perform their role and act honestly.

The Subsidiary Governance Policy sets out the corporate governance principles and requirements for IAG's subsidiaries and any other joint venture or entities it controls and, where appropriate, other entities in which the IAG Group has a minority equity interest.

The Group Security Trading Policy (Trading Policy) restricts designated people and their closely related parties from dealing in IAG securities where required. Where trading is permitted under the Trading Policy, Specified Persons (as defined in the Trading Policy) must seek approval before trading in IAG Securities.

column7: Our Code of Ethics & Conduct (Code) sets out the behaviours expected of everyone at IAG. The Code provides our people with principles and a framework to make informed business decisions. It also offers specific guidance on making the right decision and doing the right thing.

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column7: We provide an independent whistleblower reporting line, maintained 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Material cases made under the Group Whistleblower Policy are reported to Senior Management. The BRC is provided with regular reporting on whistleblower matters.

For the financial year ending 30 June 2023, IAG complied with the ASX Corporate Governance Council Corporate Governance Principles and Recommendations (4th edition). IAGÃ¢ÂÂs 2023 Corporate Governance Statement and Appendix 4G have these compliance details. This Corporate Governance Statement is current as of 21 August 2023 and has been approved by the Board.

As part of our Net Zero Roadmap commitments, we are developing a customer engagement target for our insurance-associated emissions. This target will help us to bring our customers along on the journey as our underwriting approach evolves.
Suppliers must ensure that workersÃ¢ÂÂ rights to freedom of association and collective bargaining are respected and that workers have the right to form and join trade unions by local laws.

column13: Guided by the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) Standards, we completed a comprehensive materiality assessment in FY22. This financial year, we re-examined the outcomes of that assessment with a customer survey and a review of industry and global socio-economic trends.
